text: The relapse rate for severe alcoholics attempting to quit is approximately 90%. Of the 10% who succeed permanently, the vast majority have gone through Alcoholics Anonymous. This demonstrates AA's unique effectiveness compared to other treatment modalities.

The two basic tenets of AA are: (i) surrender to a higher power, and (ii) make amends for your wrongdoings. There is no way to 'work the program' without surrendering to a higher power, making this surrender essential to recovery.

Most people who quit drinking with AA's help are self-identified agnostics and atheists prior to starting the program. There is no evidence AA is any less effective for those who enter as non-believers than for those who enter as believers, demonstrating that pre-existing religious belief is not necessary for AA's effectiveness.

William James' 'The Varieties of Religious Experience' and AA's 'Big Book' arrived at remarkably similar principles independently. Wilson arrived at these principles through his own experiences with alcoholism, not by reading James. This convergence demands explanation, especially given that the only proven treatment for alcoholism is based on these principles.

Religious sentiment cannot be understood in strictly medical terms, nor can it be deconstructed. It must be understood on its own terms. Religious sentiment gives people the strength to do what they otherwise could not do and cures people of otherwise incurable psychological maladies.

A complete absence of religious sentiment is a mark of psychopathology. Those who completely lack religious sentiment tend to be internally divided, while those who have it tend to be internally united.

Religious conversions are justified by their consequences. Although they may initially seem irrational, they often prove to be justified by their consequences. This pragmatic justification applies to both religious faith and AA's recovery program.

There is no strictly medical cure for alcoholism. It is not possible to overcome alcoholism without having a religious conversion. The rationality of this conversion is justified by its consequences, not by prior rational deliberation.

The higher power in AA is real and external—it is not a useful fiction or a projection of some aspect of one's own mind. It is not to be psychoanalyzed away or otherwise deconstructed. Surrendering to this higher power means giving it control of one's life and taking that control out of the hands of one's ego.

Empirical beliefs are necessarily underdetermined by the data, and therefore involve an element of faith—a 'will to believe.' Consequently, empirical beliefs, when justified, are justified by their consequences. Religious beliefs are justified in the same way as other empirical beliefs.

Medical science has failed to produce a cure for alcoholism and likely never will. There is no hope for the alcoholic unless he can undergo a complete psychological transformation—'an entire psychic change.' This transformation is so radical that no person could possibly carry it out on his own; a higher power is therefore necessary to effectuate this change.

The alcoholic is internally divided. He knows that he cannot have one or two drinks without getting blackout drunk, but he manages to deceive himself into thinking that he can do so. The two defining facts about the alcoholic's condition are his complete lack of self-control with respect to drinking and his ability to deceive himself about this fact.

Once the alcoholic has that first drink, he cannot will himself to stop. And yet, no matter how self-aware he is otherwise, the alcoholic is always able to convince himself that he can drink like other people. Consequently, will and self-knowledge—the two cornerstones of self-determination—are useless in alcoholism.

The alcoholic's main problem is his powerlessness over his own condition. It simply is not in his power to control his drinking. Nor is there any purely medical solution. The only remaining path is to find a higher power and surrender to it.

In addition to surrendering to a higher power, the alcoholic must make amends for all the wrongs he has done in his life. Working the steps involves cleansing his mind of resentments and other petty manifestations of ego.

The Steps are operationalized through constant action, as opposed to mere intellectual acceptance. A consequence of working the steps is that the alcoholic becomes more action-oriented and less focused on his emotions and less egocentric generally.

To avoid relapsing, the alcoholic must help others with their alcoholism. There is no way to recover from alcohol without surrendering to a higher power, and each person has his own higher power. What matters is not following AA per se but spiritually developing in such a way as to eliminate the shortcomings of character that led down the path of alcoholism.

The higher power to which the alcoholic is surrendering is his idealized self—his ego-ideal. This hypothesis is consistent with the fact that non-believers (atheists and agnostics) are able to find a higher power as readily as believers, given that believers and non-believers alike have ego-ideals.

Will must be distinguished from mere desire. A smoker desires a cigarette, but he does not will himself to have one. If he has a cigarette, it is precisely because of a lack of will. Will represents values, whereas mere desire represents urges. The alcoholic drinks because he desires to do so, not because he values doing so and therefore not because he wills to do so.

The alcoholic must experience his values projectively because he has constructed an elaborate system of rationalizations to justify his degenerate behavior. Whenever he has the urge to drink, he can rationalize doing so. If he looks inward for a reason not to drink, those rationalizations will immediately kick in. He must project his values and experience them as external entities in order to be aware of them.

The alcoholic's urge to drink is at odds with his values. He has given himself over to this urge and thereby weakened his values' ability to direct his conduct. In surrendering to his higher power and letting it guide his conduct, the alcoholic is realigning his conduct with his values, thereby mending the internal divisions that his alcoholism created.

Insanity is about replacing reality with fantasy. The insane person wants reality to play by his rules, not the other way around, and since reality won't oblige him, he withdraws into a fantasy-world that does. Drinking is a way of turning away from reality, and a compulsion to use alcohol is therefore a compulsion to be insane.

God is externalized conscience. In general, belief in God embodies wishful thinking and serves as an explanatory hypothesis, but it may also represent projected acceptance of one's own ego-ideal. Surrendering to God gives strength because one is really surrendering to one's internalized values.

Authentic religious sentiment does not necessarily involve membership in an organized religion. It necessarily involves awareness of some higher consciousness of a benevolent nature. Religious conversions are involuntary, and religious sentiment in general involves a forfeiture of ego.

In Libet's experiment, subjects pressed a button while noting when they decided to press it using a rapidly moving millisecond clock. The subject was free to press the button whenever he wanted without external prompts. The results showed that conscious awareness of the intention (W) occurred only after substantial brain activity (readiness potential, RP) had already begun.

The readiness potential (RP) begins approximately 350-550 milliseconds before conscious awareness (W) of the intention to act. W occurs approximately 200 milliseconds before the actual finger movement. This temporal sequence suggests that the operative intention precedes conscious awareness of it.

Subjects always felt as though they 'just came up with' the decision, that they 'freely' chose to move their finger, and that their decision was not the result of any previous mentation. The subject described his decision as utterly 'free,' despite the fact that brain activity preceded conscious awareness.

Libet's experiment was repeated by Libet himself and by others with hundreds of different subjects, always with the same results. The shape and length of the slope was always the same, as was the gap between RP-initiation and W, and between W and the finger-movement.

W is not the moment when the subject decides to move his finger but rather the moment when he becomes aware of an already-made decision. RP is the proximal psychological cause of the action. Since an intention is the proximal psychological cause of an action, RP is the intention and W is merely an awareness of it.

By the time W happens, RP is almost complete. Even if W is part of the intention that led to the action, it is a subordinate part with at most a facilitating function. Intentions are supposed to have a decisive role in the genesis of corresponding actions, and W clearly does not have such a role.

W is not a mere epiphenomenon. Consciousness of one's intentions necessarily has effects. If one is aware of a given intention, subsequent thought and behavior will necessarily be different from how they would otherwise have been. W, though not the intention responsible for the finger-movement in question, clearly has a hand in generating other intentions down the road.

The evidence indicates that W is not part of the operative intention. W happens very late in the game—whatever is responsible for the finger-movement is well under way by the time W makes an appearance. The pre-W part of the RP appears to be the intention itself, not merely intention-buildup.

In both graphical representations of Libet's results, W either has no effect or a slight negative effect on the trajectory of the slope. In one representation it is not an inflection-point of any kind; in another it is a slight negative inflection point where the slope decreases slightly. If W were the decision, the graph would inflect upwards after W.

Judging by the graphs, W's role is, if anything, to curb the causally effective process. W cannot possibly be an intention, let alone a decision, since such things are of their nature decisive causes. W does not have a decisive causal role.

Libet conducted a veto experiment (LE2) where subjects formed an intention to push a button at a given time but then had to refrain from doing so just before acting. The results suggest that W may have the power to 'veto' or check the execution of intentions, even if it is not the operative intention itself.

Libet's results show that 'we do not have conscious free will,' meaning that our decisions are not constituents of consciousness. The conscious events that we believe to be decisions are actually mere awarenesses of those decisions, which are formed unconsciously.

The intentions with which Libet's results are directly concerned involve real-time engagements with one's immediate environment—actions motivated by current sense-perceptions with immediate and well-defined consequences. Not all intentions fall into this category; standing intentions (like intending to write a book over three years) do not mediate real-time engagements.

Consciousness is presumably relatively heavily involved in guiding real-time engagements with the environment. Given that intentions are not constituents of consciousness where real-time actions are concerned, it is doubly unlikely that they are constituents of consciousness where other forms of action (like standing intentions) are concerned.

A standing intention demonstrably cannot be a constituent of consciousness. An intention to create a new trading platform is an enduring structure, like knowledge that 2+2=4. One can be conscious of it, but it is not itself a constituent of consciousness.

Libet's experiment shows that we do not have 'conscious free will'—it shows that our decisions, even those governing real-time responses to the environment, are not constituents of consciousness and that we are not even conscious of them until after an appreciable time-lapse (.2 seconds).

The .2 second delay between intention and awareness is very possibly not mere tape-delay. Consciousness operates extremely quickly—the average sprinter takes around .2 seconds per step and can be conscious of each step and even step-components. This suggests that the delay reflects W's function rather than being minimal processing time.

In 1998, Patrick Haggard's team replicated Libet's experiment and also measured 'lateralized' readiness-potentials (LRP's) for actions where subjects could choose which hand to use. Lateralized readiness-potentials are virtually indistinguishable from regular RP's: they begin at the same time relative to both W and the finger-movement, and they have the same trajectories.

In 2008, Chun Siong Soon's team used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), which is much more accurate and high-resolution than EEG. They found that the relevant RP's began much earlier than Libet's experiment had indicated, sometimes preceding W by as much as 10 seconds.

In 2010, Itzhak Fried's team used depth-electrodes to determine RP onset-time, making it possible to identify the very first neural firing and the 'neuronal recruitment' process. Fried found that the relevant RP began 1500 ms (1.5 seconds) prior to W—1.3 seconds prior to the time at which Libet detected RP-onset with less sensitive technology.

In 2012, Aaron Schurger's team conducted Libet's study while subjects heard randomly distributed clicking noises during the interval between RP-onset and W. These distracting clicks had no appreciable effect on the shape of the RP or the positions of W and the finger-movement. This suggests that prior to W, the RP is robust and overwhelmingly likely to eventuate in action.

Many follow-up studies have been conducted; none have impugned Libet's results and most if not all have confirmed them. These studies suggest that Libet was even more right than he thought: the operative RP is initiated even earlier than Libet thought, and once initiated, it is overwhelmingly likely to result in action.

Considered on their own terms, Libet's results are straightforward: What we believe to be choices that are initiated in consciousness are not initiated in consciousness; they are initiated prior to any conscious awareness of them and far outside any such awareness.

It may be unclear how Libet's results bear on the question 'do we have free will?', but that is more a reflection of the unclarity of that question than of those results. It isn't at all clear what it means to say someone has 'free will' or what a self is or whether there is a self wherever there is sentience.

Determinism is the doctrine that the state of the universe at any given time fixes the state at any later time. Compatibilism holds that free will is compatible with determinism. Incompatibilism (libertarianism) holds that compatibilism is false.

The motivation for incompatibilism: If determinism is the case, then what any person is doing on any occasion is the inevitable consequence of the state of the universe before that person's birth, and it is hard to see how someone could be free under such circumstances.

The motivation for compatibilism: To the extent that the external world is indeterministic, one's ability to control it, and therefore one's freedom, is abridged. If there is a 72% chance a call goes through versus 84%, one has less control with the lower probability. Determinism appears necessary for power over oneself and therefore for freedom.

If thought-processes are not predetermined, they come out of nowhere; they aren't rooted in one's beliefs, values, or intentions; they are mere visitations. If thoughts totally lacked a causal basis in one's pre-existing psychological structures, it is unclear why those thoughts would be his thoughts; they would be free-floating thoughts.

Thoughts that lacked a causal basis in one's pre-existing condition would seem to be intrusions—similar to an obsessive-compulsive's 'intrusive thoughts.' Though uncaused, they would not represent that person exercising his agency; they would be undergone by him and therefore would neither give him freedom nor represent deployments of any freedom he might have.

We only have freedom to the extent that the world, including ourselves, is deterministic. Indeterminism threatens freedom; there doesn't seem to be any respect in which any form of indeterminism makes us free. Determinism seems to be a prerequisite for freedom, at least insofar as it is possible to have freedom.

There seems to be at least a kind of freedom compatible with determinism. I am acting freely, at least after a fashion, when my actions align with my values and represent a fulfillment of my biological program. If in making a decision I am exercising my rationality to the greatest extent possible and choosing a path that will enhance rather than diminish me, then arguably I am acting freely.

Libet's results are quite clear: When it comes to actions involved in real-time engagements with the environment, intention-mediating RP's predate the conscious events that people are inclined to believe are their intentions. There is nothing unclear about this fact per se, even if it's unclear what we ought to infer about the mind from it.

Adina Roskies' position is that neuroscience has no philosophical significance. Neuroscience merely shows us how intentions, beliefs, and so on are physiologically implemented, but doesn't otherwise give us information about them and certainly doesn't warrant revision of our pretheoretic judgments about them.

Roskies claims that neuroscientific results 'dovetail nicely' with traditional philosophical views, specifically compatibilist views of agency. According to her, Libet's experiment concerns only 'low level' semi-automatic actions and has nothing to do with non-automatic actions like deciding to start a hedge fund.

The actions with which Libet's results are concerned are not reflexes: unlike reflexes, they are driven by intentions. Libet's results give us new and counterintuitive information about those intentions, showing that conscious events we thought to be the essence of decision-making are either not involved, peripherally involved, or involved totally differently from how we previously thought.

The idea that neuroscientific research 'dovetails nicely' with compatibilist views is misleading. According to compatibilism, you are free even though your actions are predetermined. But Libet's experiment shows that your center of consciousness has a rather oblique and tenuous relationship to paradigm cases of 'free' action.

Libet's experiment definitively shows that one's center of consciousness—what people intuitively regard as the center of their very selves—has a much more subordinate role in decision-making than people, including philosophers, assume. This is not fully compatible with compatibilism as traditionally understood.

Ferdinard Fosu-Blankson claims Libet is guilty of over-generalization or 'hasty generalization.' His position is that Libet's results only apply to finger-movements and cannot be generalized to other body-movements. This is an extraordinarily weak point—it would be profoundly odd if the results held for finger-movements but not leg-movements or arm-movements.

Libet's experiment is set up to maximize the role of consciousness in the actions in question. The subject is wide awake, given explicit instructions, and can push the button whenever he wants within the relevant multi-minute time-window. He is not told to do anything involving protracted thought that would rely disproportionately on unconscious thought. What he is told to do is about as consciousness-centered as an action can be.

Some philosophers claim Libet is confusing correlation with causation—that yes, the RP precedes the finger-movement and W, but that doesn't mean it causes either. However, the RP obviously does cause the finger-movement; either that or it is temporally coincident with whatever the cause is. Either way, W is not the operative intention.

Looking at the graphical representation, the finger-movement happens right at the top of the RP curve, at which point it plummets. Clearly, the curve tracks whatever it is that causes the finger-movement. Whatever this cause is, W is not an important part of it or simply not a part of it.

Some philosophers question Libet's experimental data, claiming that empirical processes 'cannot yield accurate picture of what transpired in the conscious configuration of the participants.' However, Libet's results have been duplicated many times over. While margin-of-error issues can arise in experiments, there is no reason to believe such problems are operative in this context.

Alfred Mele claims Libet's experimental data cannot be trusted because we don't know exactly when W occurs; we only know when the subject says W occurs. He suggests that when we account for gaps between these events, there is no reason to deny that W is coeval with the operative intention.

For Libet's results to fall into margin-of-error territory, the subject would have to be very wrong about when W occurs—reporting W when the dial was at 0 when it was actually at 40. Although theoretically possible, there is no independent corroborating evidence for this. Libet's findings are confirmed by later studies with more sensitive technology where the gap between RP and W is too large to chalk up to error-margin issues.

Mele distinguishes between 'proximal intentions' (intentions to perform actions in real-time engagement with the environment, like running from a growling dog) and 'distal intentions' (intentions to perform actions in the future, like writing a dissertation). This distinction is valid, and Libet's results only directly concern proximal intentions.

Distal intentions are extremely unlikely to be more consciousness-based than proximal intentions. Because distal intentions are of their nature relatively enduring psychological structures rather than mental events, they cannot possibly be identical with the ephemera that populate consciousness. It is theoretically possible that decisions leading to such intentions are identical with conscious events, but there is no evidence to suggest this.

People often find themselves carrying out intentions they did not consciously form. There isn't necessarily a 'moment' when one decided to study finance or invent a new trading platform. Sometimes distal intentions result from conscious epiphanies, but they do not appear to do so categorically.

Some philosophers claim the 'actions' studied by Libet are so low-level that they are more like reflexes than bona fide actions, and little if anything is to be inferred from them about the nature of intentions. However, the behaviors with which Libet's results are concerned are textbook cases of bona fide actions—of non-automatic, non-reflexive, 'freely made' actions.

The actions in Libet's experiment are textbook cases of what we would ordinarily regard as 'conscious.' The subject was free to choose when to push the button; he was not given incentives to push it at one time versus another; the context was not emotionally driven; the subject was not given subliminal messages or manipulated, conditioned, or programmed, and his consciousness was not otherwise circumvented.

Nicholas Rescher argues that the suite of events Libet is studying (the event-chain comprising RP and W) does not consist of 'parts,' and we therefore cannot say that some early 'part' is responsible for some later 'part.' He claims RPI is simply the first part of a single, indivisible unit that is 'atomic' and 'indissoluble.'

Rescher's argument is question-begging. Libet's results show that W is not as causally important as previously thought, and therefore show that philosophical views like Rescher's are empirically false. Most causality is 'processual,' mediated by processes. A light-beam is a textbook case of a causal process; so are a gust of wind, a rolling ball, and a growing fetus. The RP is a textbook case of such a process.

Rescher claims Libet confuses correlation with causation, arguing that earlier parts of RP need not exert 'causal priority' over later phases. He compares this to days of the week (Monday doesn't cause Tuesday). However, the earlier parts of RP clearly do exert causal priority over later phases, and causal connectivity clearly holds between them. The comparison with days of the week is misconceived.

Hans Radder and Gerben Meynen argue that RP-onset is not an INUS-condition for W occurring .2 seconds later. (x is an INUS condition for y iff x is an insufficient but non-redundant part of an unnecessary but sufficient condition for y.) They claim there is no data indicating RP is sufficient for the occurrence of W at the specific time .2 seconds later.

There is a wealth of experimental data supporting the claim that RP-onset causes W at a specific time interval. When Libet's experiment is perfectly replicated, the delay is consistently around .2 seconds. When the experiment varies (e.g., subject can click with either hand), the gap between RP-onset and W, though not necessarily the same, is consistent.

Radder and Meynen argue that to establish x causes y, we need to establish that changes in x-like events lead to changes in y-like events. They claim we cannot possibly know this where RP and W are concerned. However, many different Libet-style experiments have shown that the length of the RP and the relative positions of RP-onset and W depend in a consistent manner on the exact task the subject is asked to perform.

A recurring theme in philosophical literature is that Libet confuses urges with intentions. This view holds that W is indeed the operative decision—prior to W, RP is a mere urge and not anything that will by itself lead to action. W is needed to convert this intention-precursor into an actual intention.

If W is indeed a decision, then it has a decisive role in causing the finger-movement. But it doesn't. Looking at the graphs, W does not have a decisive role in causing the finger-movement. The finger-movement happens at the vertex of the curve because that curve reached its vertex. Whatever W's role is, it is not decisive, and therefore it isn't a decision.

Judging by the graph, W is the opposite of decisive; it is in the last place that a decision to act would be. If W happened at the very beginning of the slope, it could be a decision (it would clearly be what caused the finger-movement). If it happened at the peak, it could be a decision (it might convert an erstwhile urge into a veritable intention). But W happens far too late to launch the process and too early to transform it.

Tim Bayne argues that Libet's experiment concerns actions requiring no thought or deliberation and therefore only minimally engaging the subject's agency. He claims Libet-actions involve 'disinterested agency' where the agent has no reason to flex their wrist at one time rather than another. He calls these manifestations of 'liberty of indifference.'

Bayne's claim lacks experimental support. Moreover, the more deliberation and 'rational reflection' are involved in an action, the less likely the operative intention is to be fully conscious. The actions studied in Libet's experiment are probably not as one-dimensional as claimed. Pushing a button at random intervals requires more thought than pushing it at regular intervals—in the latter case one can go on autopilot; in the former, one cannot.

Some philosophers claim it is a 'phenomenological datum' that we have free will—we 'just know' it, and such knowledge is etched into the very structure of the human mind. They argue that without human experience in aetiology and decision-making, there would not emerge a conception of free will, and the reality of free will is experienced rather than covert.

The position that free will is a phenomenological datum is straightforwardly question-begging. The comparison with the cogito is also misconceived. The cogito is to the effect that I couldn't think unless I existed; its truth is trivial and analytic (its negation is incoherent). But there is nothing trivial about asserting I have free will. Free will, if it exists, is a form of causation, and it is always an open empirical question what causes what.

Libet's experiment has been replicated many times, always with the same results. Similar studies involving different measuring instruments and different tasks have generated results consistent with Libet's. While it is a theoretical possibility that the results are spurious, it is only a theoretical possibility.

Libet's results directly establish that where some actions are concerned, the conscious events we believe to be our intentions are not our intentions. This suggests that those conscious events are mere awarenesses of the corresponding intentions.

Libet's results show definitively that the conscious event the subject experiences as being identical with his decision to move his finger is not his decision. Indeed, it is not even involved in that decision; it is on the sidelines, at least vis-à-vis that particular decision. The center of consciousness that the subject identifies as the nucleus of his decision is merely an awareness of that decision, made by some other party.

The subject experiences his center of consciousness as being the essence of his agency, at least where 'conscious' actions are concerned, but that isn't what it is. This is a striking result, and contrary to what some philosophers allege, it is hard to compatibilize with compatibilism.

Compatibilism says you are free even though you are determined. It doesn't deny that you act; rather, it says how you act is predetermined and you are free so long as operative mechanisms meet certain conditions. But what Libet's experiment shows is not so much that you are determined as it is that you are on the sidelines. By the time you make an appearance, the decision has already been made.

What is ominous about Libet's experiment is not so much that it shows your choices to be predetermined but that it shows them not to be yours. They are yours to behold, but not to make. It is one thing if your actions resulted from conscious, albeit predetermined, decisions—this is what compatibilists believe. It is very different if what you thought were operative conscious decisions are in fact non-operative.

Libet's experiment is not just an iteration of the old idea that choices have causes. It is proof that what we thought were choices aren't. It is also proof that the center of consciousness that a person regards as the nucleus of his very self, and of his agency in particular, isn't.

In a way, what Libet's experiment shows is even more radical than what Freud showed. Freud showed that some mental activity, including some decisions, are made unconsciously, sometimes resulting in internal conflict. But Freud was not saying that your conscious decisions, or what you believe to be your conscious decisions, are lame ducks.

Freud's position is that consciousness is like a monarch whose power, though considerable, is limited. Freud didn't deny that what we take to be our conscious decisions are in fact conscious decisions; nor did he deny that these conscious decisions represented the very nucleus of our agency. Freud regarded this central conscious authority as indeed a central authority, albeit a weak one—like a ruler who, though weak, is not a puppet.

Libet's work shows that in the very contexts where the conscious ruler least appears to be a puppet, that is precisely what he is—when he is most certain that he is calling the shots, he is in fact a mere spectator who isn't even told what the shots are until after they have been fired.

Libet's finding is a dark and hard-to-absorb point, and it is not compatible with any well-developed philosophical position concerning human agency. All such positions assume that the events we regard as our conscious choices are indeed our conscious choices, with the qualification that those choices are 'free' according to some positions but not according to others.

Even if W is epiphenomenal with respect to the corresponding intention, it is not epiphenomenal tout court. There is evidence that W can 'veto' a pre-existing intention. But W's significance likely extends far beyond that.

Consciousness is real-time awareness. There are two kinds: real-time awarenesses of external events (sense-perceptions) and real-time awarenesses of internal processes (introspections). Introspections can be pains, pleasures, occurrent thoughts about pains and pleasures, mental images, gnawing doubts, inchoate aches, etc.

One purpose of consciousness is to integrate information about the external world with information about the internal world. Consciousness pools these two datasets, and decisions as to how to maximize the subject's welfare are made on that basis. The presumption is that consciousness makes such decisions, but that is not the case, at least not if Libet's results are to be trusted.

What consciousness does do is either approve or disapprove of decisions already made. Libet himself has provided reason to believe it can disapprove of them. It also actively approves of them, if only after the fact, with the qualification that these conscious acts of decision-approval are experienced as conscious acts of decision-making.

Why are acts of decision-approval experienced as decision-making instead? After a fashion, these acts are decisions—decisions to green-light an existing intention. Also, if they were experienced as exactly what they are (approving an intention made by some other party), that might overburden consciousness.

One makes innumerably many choices within the space of a single minute. If one's conscious awarenesses of these choices were overly fine-grained, the result would be to bog down consciousness in matters with which it needn't concern itself. The 'illusion of free choice' is a small price to pay for this gain in efficiency.

In approving of a given intention, W, though not the cause of that particular intention, does implicitly green-light future similar intentions. In other words, it tells the relevant part of one's mind to carry on apace. If W vetoes a given action, it tells it to redirect its efforts. So W does have a directive role with respect to future intentions, granting that it serves to approve or disapprove of the intention with which the subject mistakenly believes it to be identical.

Consider the standards of proof and evidence that philosophers are using in connection with Libet's data. By those standards, there is no reason to believe that smoking causes cancer. But it does, and we know that, because that is what the data shows.

If it turns out that the data generated by Libet's experiment and by the various replication and follow-up studies is spurious, so be it. In the meantime, we should probably accept that data and try to model it. By refusing to model it—by insisting that it must be spurious—philosophers are blinding themselves to valuable information about the nature of agency.

Wilfred Sellars destroyed the 'myth of the given' and began a revolution in epistemology. Foundationalism used to be the orthodoxy; nowadays, because of Sellars, anti-foundationalism is the orthodoxy. Two hundred years before Sellars, George Berkeley destroyed the myth of the given by means of an argument very similar to Sellars'.

The foundationalist conception: No empirical background knowledge is needed to obtain knowledge of external reality. A given perception can do that on its own. All empirical knowledge rests on top of perceptions. Perceptions cannot, and therefore do not, rest on top of empirical knowledge. Therefore perceptions provide us with knowledge of the external world without the assistance of any background knowledge.

Sellars demolished the foundationalist picture. He is not denying that external realities are given to us through sense-perceptions—no one would seriously deny that. Sellars is attacking the idea that when a perception makes us aware of some external state of affairs, it does so without the cooperation of a manifold of preexisting empirical knowledge.

There are two senses in which, for Sellars, knowledge acquired through perception is not 'given.' It is not a given in the sense that its existence typically presupposes a background of empirical knowledge. Background knowledge must be mobilized if a sensory experience is to give us knowledge of an external state of affairs. What is given (the sensory experience considered apart from background knowledge) is not epistemic—it does not constitute knowledge of anything.

Sellars makes a stronger claim: The significance of a quale—what it truly or falsely tells the subject, leaving aside what the subject knows in virtue of having it—is not given; it is not fixed, at least not by the intrinsic properties of the quale. The quale has to be filtered through background knowledge first; then the quale gives the subject a determinate message about the external world.

The epistemic significance of a quale is not fixed or 'given'; it is a variable function of background empirical knowledge. Sellars is against the idea that 'raw sensations' by themselves have a fixed or 'given' message and thus don't need the co-operation of ulterior knowledge to tell us anything, whether true or false, about the outside world.

There are two myths of the given: (i) What is given is epistemic, i.e. constitutes knowledge. (ii) What is given is representational, i.e. it tells us anything, whether true or false. Sellars made a compelling case against both myths.

According to Sellars, what is false is not the belief that there is a given. Obviously the perceiver is passive in some respects; some things are given to him. What is false is the belief that the given is epistemic (constitutes knowledge) and also that what is given is even representational.

Berkeley's argument in 'An Essay Towards a New Theory of Vision' (1709) made essentially the same points that Sellars would make over two hundred years later in 'Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind.' Berkeley's attack on the given is more perspicuous, more radical, and more cogent than Sellars' version.

Sellars' tie-shop argument: Bob is in a tie shop with unusual lighting. He cannot tell whether he is looking at a green or blue tie. He takes the tie outside where lighting is 'standard' and sees it is blue. He goes back inside and realizes what a blue tie looks like under the unusual lighting. After repeating this with many colors, he can tell what color a tie is without leaving the shop—even though a blue tie in the shop gives off the same appearance as a green tie under standard lighting.

When Post-Bob (Bob after acclimatization) sees what color a tie is in the tie-shop, a great deal of background empirical knowledge is at work. He knows about the conditions of perception in the tie-shop and how they affect appearance. Post-Bob can upload the color of the tie from his perception only because there is a fair amount of existing empirical knowledge operating in his cognitive background.

What Sellars says about Post-Bob's way of ascertaining tie colors applies to how we obtain knowledge of objects' perceptible properties under 'standard' conditions. When we are just looking at an object and seeing that it is red, the perception involved is informed by background empirical knowledge in just the way that Post-Bob's perception is thus informed.

The conditions of perception under which we sense-perceive objects are in a constant state of flux. In some cases those changes are quite dramatic. But unless the changes are highly unusual, we adjust automatically and unthinkingly. You simply see that some tie is red in circumstances where lighting conditions are quite non-standard (unless they are exceptionally non-standard).

Standard conditions are an idealization: no conditions are really standard. If there were perfectly 'standard' conditions, they would not be standard. If we could set up a situation that was distortion-free, that situation would not be a typical one. So what Sellars says about Bob's intake of color-facts in the tie-shop is true of our intake of color-facts in general.

A diamond-shaped object looked at from above gives off the same appearance as a square-shaped object looked at from an oblique angle. But we instantly know, except in contrived circumstances, whether an object is diamond-shaped or square. We see that it is square. How can we see this, given that its appearance could just as well be that of a diamond-shaped object? Because we take into account a great deal of contextual information; in particular, we take into account that we are not hovering above the object.

A ten foot stop-sign looked at from a hundred feet away gives off the same appearance as a 1,000 foot stop sign looked at from 10,000 feet away. But when one looks at a stop sign from a hundred feet away, one sees that it is a stop sign of a certain approximate height. One can just see the approximate height, but how is this possible given the ambiguous appearance? Because one takes a great deal of contextual information into account—comparing the sign to nearby trees and using other benchmarks.

Any episode of taking in information about the external world—any episode of taking in the height or speed or shape or color of an object—involves the co-operation of contextual or background information. Such ulterior knowledge is needed to give content to one's sensory episodes. Otherwise those episodes are indeterminate.

In the absence of background empirical knowledge, our sensory episodes become indeterminate to the point of meaninglessness—to the point of having no representational content. If contextual information is left out, one's visual sensations don't tell one whether one is seeing a thousand-foot object ten-thousand feet away or a ten-foot object a hundred feet away; whether one is seeing a diamond or a square; an oval or a circle; a nearby object moving 3 mph or a distant one moving at 150,000 mph.

Berkeley's argument: We think we can simply see whether an object is ten feet away or a thousand feet away, whether it is oval or round. Of course we do learn objects' shapes, sizes, and so on through perception, and through sight in particular. Berkeley doesn't deny this. But he says that when we take in the shape of an object through sight, that is only because a great deal of background knowledge is co-operating.

Berkeley begins by asking us to consider distance-perception. We think we see how far away objects are. Obviously we can (up to a point) take in objects' distances from us through sight. But one obviously cannot tell, just by looking at it, that the moon is this or that distance away. This is always true, in a very obvious way, of very distant objects.

According to Berkeley, what is true of very distant objects is true, though less obviously, of not-so-distant objects. Given only what your eyes tell you—leaving aside background knowledge—do you really know that you are seeing a medium-sized object fifty feet away or a massive object a mile away? Your visual experience by itself is ambiguous between seeing a massive object very far away and a medium-sized object nearby. So you don't really see how far away an object is.

When you think you are seeing how far away an object is, you are really reading into your visual experience a lot of background empirical knowledge. You know that objects of that particular shape (say, a stop-sign shape) are typically of such and such a height, and you use that information as a benchmark. Given that background information, you can tell on the basis of your visual sensation that you are seeing an object less than a hundred feet away.

The appearance given off by a receding object is not different from the appearance given off by a shrinking object. But when you see a person walk into the distance, you can see that he is not shrinking. How can you see this, given that the appearance could be that of a shrinking person? You know that people don't shrink. You also know that if a person were suddenly shrinking, he wouldn't make the calm ambulatory motions made by the person you are seeing. Thus contextual information disambiguates what would otherwise be an ambiguous visual experience.

According to Berkeley, what ultimately endows one's visual sensations with information regarding distances is that different kinds of visual sensations have different kinds of kinesthetic and tactile concomitants. One reads these into one's current visual sensations and this, in the final analysis, gives your visual experiences the representational contents they have.

Berkeley's basic point: Your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the size or distance of the object. What does that is your visual experience plus various pieces of background knowledge. '[T]he judgment we make of the distance of an object viewed with both eyes is entirely the result of experience. If we had not constantly found that certain sensations accompanied our visual sensations, we would never make those sudden judgments from them concerning the distance of objects.'

Berkeley sometimes says you simply don't see distances at all. This seems an overstatement—in some sense, surely, I can see that my pencil is less than 90 ft away. But there is a deep truth in Berkeley's words. One's visual experience, taken by itself, stripped of any contextualization, doesn't tell one whether one is seeing a tree-size pencil a half-mile off or a tiny pencil nearby.

Berkeley generalizes his point about distance to shape. It is only 'past experience' that teaches us that a paradigmatic-square appearance betokens a square object. If the tactile/kinesthetic sensations we associate with diamond-shaped objects accompanied a square appearance, that square appearance would betoken a diamond-shaped object, not a square one.

Berkeley has a definite answer to Molyneux's question: Consider a man born blind who was one day given sight. Would he know on the basis of his visual perceptions—before having a chance to correlate them with tactile, kinesthetic, or other sensations—whether he was seeing a round or an oval or a square object? Berkeley explicitly says 'no.'

It is not one's visual perceptions by themselves that tell one whether one is seeing a slow or fast moving object. If one's visual sensations are to apprise one of how fast some object is moving, they need the assistance of a great deal of ulterior information. (If I thought the plane I saw was only ten feet above me, I would think it was only moving 3 mph. Since I know it is thousands of feet above me, I can 'see' that it is moving very quickly.)

Berkeley illustrates his major point with analogies. When you hear somebody talk, you feel as though you directly grasp their meaning. You hear through the sounds to the meaning. But the relationship between sounds and meaning is arbitrary, and you could only know it through experience (being brought up in an English-speaking country or taking English classes). You 'hear' the meaning only with the help of background knowledge.

Your visual experiences apprise you of the squareness of objects only in the sense in which your auditory perceptions apprise you of the meaning of a spoken sentence. You think you just see the shape of an object—that your visual experience by itself tells you what shape it has. But you are reading a great deal of background information into your visual experience.

Another Berkeley analogy: When a person's face reddens (in a particular way), that indicates shame. When you see that reddening, you feel as though you can actually see the shame. But surely your visual experience by itself doesn't apprise you of the other person's shame; a great deal of background knowledge of how people's emotions are given bodily expression is at work.

Berkeley's major point: No sensory experience by itself tells one anything. Any such experience has to be put in the context of a lot of background knowledge if it is to bear any determinate message and if therefore it is to tell one anything about the external world. So no sensory experience is foundational: the senses tell us about the world only through the 'mediation of various past experiences.'

There is no given; there are no foundational sensory experiences. Knowledge of the external world is obtained by putting one's current sensory experiences into the context of other sensory experiences and also in the context of previously obtained empirical knowledge. Empirical knowledge is obtained through coherencies obtaining among sensory experiences; it isn't given through isolated sensory experiences.

For Berkeley, empirical knowledge has no foundation. At bottom, this is just what Sellars was saying: it is Sellarsian anti-foundationalism. Berkeley's argument for epistemic anti-foundationalism is far more lucid and developed than Sellars' version.

There are two respects in which Berkeley's argument is superior to Sellars'. First, Sellars only gives one example relating to perception of just one kind of property (a secondary property, color) under non-standard conditions. If Sellars' argument for anti-foundationalism is to be made cogent, it must be generalized to other properties (e.g. distance, shape) and shown to apply to standard (or not grossly unusual) conditions.

Berkeley's argument is not subject to the limitations of scope that constrain Sellars' argument. Berkeley's argument directly shows anti-foundationalism to hold for our perceptual intake of virtually every perceptible property. Berkeley gives explicit arguments for distance, shape, and motion, and these arguments can easily be adapted to mass, temperature, and other properties.

The philosophical literature on Libet illustrates a hyper-defensive manner in which philosophers have tended to respond to the Libet experiment. Arguments that are not prohibitively vague are demonstrably false, yet they recur repeatedly as attempts to minimize or circumscribe the significance of empirical findings.

If W were a transformative decision, it would have to convert a pre-existing urge into an intention. But looking at the position of W on the RP curve, the probability that W is transformative or decisive would be minimal. W happens far too late to launch the process and too early to transform it into its final state.

Suppose a statistician, physicist, or biologist were looking at Libet's graph without knowing what it represented—only that it represented some process. Relative to this information, the probability they would assign to W being transformative or decisive would be minimal. To say that W is transformative simply contravenes the data; to say it must be transformative begs the question.

Some philosophers claim Libet's results don't generalize because they concern actions that fail to engage the subject's rationality. According to this view, LE is concerned with actions requiring no thought or deliberation and therefore only minimally engaging the subject's agency. However, this position lacks experimental support.

According to Spinoza: 'If a stone became conscious while falling, it would think that it was falling of its own free will.' This captures the essence of what Libet's experiment reveals about the relationship between consciousness and agency.

The more constructive approach to Libet's results is to accept them, if only tentatively, and try to model them. What is proposed may be speculative and even personal in character, but it represents a good faith attempt to model the quite striking data generated by the experiment.

Libet's results show quite definitively that the conscious event the subject experiences as being identical with his decision to move his finger is not his decision to move his finger. The consciousness that the subject identifies as the nucleus of his decision is merely an awareness of that decision, and that decision was therefore made by some other party.

It is not just W that is being discussed; it is the W-analogue present in every other 'conscious' action—the 'center of consciousness' that each represents. The subject experiences this center of consciousness as being the essence of his agency, at least where 'conscious' actions are concerned, but that isn't what it is.

This is a striking result, and contrary to what some philosophers allege, it is hard to compatibilize with compatibilism as traditionally understood. The issue is not merely that you are determined (as compatibilism addresses) but that by the time you make an appearance, the decision has already been made—you are on the sidelines.

What is ominous about the Libet experiment is not so much that it shows your choices to be predetermined but that it shows them not to be yours. Your 'choices' are yours to behold, but not to make. This is fundamentally different from the compatibilist picture where actions result from conscious, albeit predetermined, decisions.

Freud's conception of consciousness differs fundamentally from what Libet shows. Freud regarded consciousness as like a monarch whose power, though considerable, is limited—a central authority, albeit a weak one, like a ruler who though weak is not a puppet. Freud didn't deny that what we take to be conscious decisions are in fact conscious decisions.

Libet's work shows that in the very contexts where the conscious ruler least appears to be a puppet—when he is most certain that he is calling the shots—he is in fact a mere spectator who isn't even told what the shots are until after they have been fired. This is more radical than Freud's findings.

Libet's finding is not compatible with any well-developed philosophical position concerning human agency. All such positions assume that the events we regard as our conscious choices are indeed our conscious choices, with only disagreement over whether those choices are 'free.' Libet's experiment shows this foundational assumption to be false.

A tentative model of W's function: Consciousness is real-time awareness that takes two forms: real-time awareness of external events (sense-perceptions) and real-time awareness of internal processes. One purpose of consciousness is to integrate these two bodies of information—pooling information about the external and internal worlds so decisions can be made to maximize the subject's welfare.

The presumption is that consciousness makes decisions to maximize welfare, but Libet's results show this is not the case. What consciousness does do is either approve or disapprove of decisions already made. Libet has provided reason to believe it can disapprove of them (veto function), and it also actively approves of them, though these acts of approval are experienced as acts of decision-making.

Why are acts of decision-approval experienced as decision-making? After a fashion, these acts are decisions—decisions to green-light an existing intention. If they were experienced as exactly what they are (approving an intention made by another party), that might overburden consciousness with excessive fine-grained awareness of innumerable choices made within a single minute.

The 'illusion of free choice'—experiencing decision-approval as decision-making—is a small price to pay for efficiency gains. It prevents consciousness from being bogged down in matters with which it needn't concern itself.

In approving of a given intention, W implicitly green-lights future similar intentions—it tells the relevant part of one's mind to carry on apace. If W vetoes an action, it redirects those efforts. So W does have a directive role with respect to future intentions, even though it serves to approve or disapprove of the intention with which the subject mistakenly believes it to be identical.

Looking at Libet's graph without knowing what it represents: suppose you didn't know this was a graph of a decision-making process, only that it describes a growth-process of some kind. Under these circumstances, the idea that W (a point two-thirds up the slope) is a crucial event in the process in question is absurd.

W is the conscious event the subject believes to be his decision to move his finger. W clearly isn't the cause of the finger-movement. These are the facts. One can always play skeptic with various objections, but in this context those are merely cards that can be played.

Judging by various replication-studies and follow-up studies, there is no reason to believe that Libet's data is in any way spurious and there is every reason to believe that the results generalize beyond the specific experimental setup.

By the standards of proof and evidence philosophers use in connection with Libet's data, there is no reason to believe smoking causes cancer. But it does, and we know that because that is what the data shows. The same evidential standards should apply to Libet's experimental results.

We should accept Libet's data and try to model it. By refusing to model it—by insisting that it must be spurious—philosophers are blinding themselves to valuable information about the nature of agency, specifically about the role of our so-called 'conscious decisions' therein.

A model has been put forth, albeit an extremely schematic one, as to the agentive function of conscious mental events like W. If nothing else, this model is consistent with the data generated by Libet's experiment. We stand to learn about the mind by investigating the merits of such models rather than by insisting that Libet 'must' be wrong.

Libet's experiment represents an extremely valuable but missed opportunity for the discipline of philosophy. The defensive, dismissive responses from philosophers represent a failure to engage constructively with significant empirical findings about the nature of mind and agency.

Libet's study used an EEG (electroencephalogram), which measures electrical activity in the brain on the basis of temperature-changes in the subject's scalp. This was the technology available in the early 1980s, and while less precise than later methods, it was sufficient to detect the relevant patterns.

Soon's 2008 study used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), which measures brain activity based on changes in oxygenation levels in the brain. fMRI is much more accurate and high-resolution than EEG, allowing for more precise temporal and spatial localization of brain activity.

Fried's 2010 study used depth-electrodes as opposed to EEG or fMRI. This made it possible to identify the very first neural firing involved in the RP and to identify the 'neuronal recruitment' process whereby additional neural firings came to be involved in the decision-making process.

The gap between RP-onset and W was found to be 1.5 seconds in Fried's study using depth-electrodes, compared to approximately 0.35-0.55 seconds in Libet's original EEG-based study. This represents a 1.3 second difference attributable to the greater sensitivity of the measurement technology.

Schurger's 2012 experiment tested the robustness of the RP by introducing distracting stimuli (randomly distributed clicking noises) during the interval between RP-onset and W. The fact that these had no appreciable effect on the shape of the RP or the timing of W and the finger-movement suggests that the RP, once initiated, is a robust process overwhelmingly likely to eventuate in action.

The subject in Libet's experiment established the time of W by coordinating it with the position of a dial on a clock that made one full rotation every 500 ms (.5 seconds). This provided a precise temporal marker for when the subject first became consciously aware of the intention to act.

For Libet's results to fall into margin-of-error territory based on timing inaccuracies, the subject would have to be very wrong about when W occurred—reporting W when the dial was at 0 when it was actually at 40. This degree of error is theoretically possible but has no independent corroborating evidence.

The distinction between proximal and distal intentions is completely valid. Proximal intentions mediate real-time engagements with the environment (e.g., running from a growling dog), while distal intentions concern future or extended actions (e.g., writing a dissertation). Libet's results only directly concern proximal intentions.

Even though Libet's results directly concern only proximal intentions, distal intentions are extremely unlikely to be more consciousness-based than proximal intentions. Distal intentions, being relatively enduring psychological structures rather than mental events, cannot possibly be identical with the ephemera that populate consciousness.

People often find themselves carrying out intentions they did not consciously form. There isn't necessarily a 'moment' when one decided to study finance or invent a new trading platform. Sometimes distal intentions result, or at least seem to result, from conscious epiphanies, but they do not appear to do so categorically.

The behaviors with which Libet's results are concerned are textbook cases of bona fide actions—of non-automatic, non-reflexive, 'freely made' (whatever that means) actions. They are simple, yes, but not reflexive or otherwise unintentional.

Those actions in Libet's experiment are textbook cases of what we would ordinarily regard as 'conscious.' The subject was free to choose when to push the button; he was not given incentives to push it at one time versus another; the context was not emotionally driven; he was not given subliminal messages, manipulated, conditioned, or programmed; his consciousness was not circumvented.

The experiment was set up to maximize the role of consciousness in the relevant action. Consequently, the behaviors in question were the exact opposite of being reflexes or semi-automatic actions—they were maximally consciousness-involving actions.

Rescher's argument that RP is an 'indivisible' or 'atomic' process whose parts cannot be separated is question-begging. It assumes what needs to be proven—that W has equal causal importance to earlier parts of the RP—in order to dismiss evidence suggesting otherwise.

Most causality is 'processual,' meaning it is mediated by processes. A light-beam is a textbook case of a causal process; so are a gust of wind, a rolling ball, and a growing fetus. The RP is a textbook case of such a process, and it is absurd to suppose that events composing the RP at a given time are not effects of events composing the RP at earlier times.

Rescher's invocation of 'backward causation' and 'noncausal connectivity' represents red herrings. The earlier parts of the RP clearly do exert causal priority over the later phases, and causal connectivity clearly holds between them. The comparison with days of the week (Monday doesn't cause Tuesday) is misconceived.

Some philosophers use highly technical philosophical concepts like 'INUS conditions' (insufficient but non-redundant part of an unnecessary but sufficient condition) to argue against the causal interpretation of RP. However, these technical arguments often obscure rather than illuminate the straightforward causal relationships visible in the data.

When Libet's experiment is perfectly replicated, the delay between RP-onset and W is consistently in the neighborhood of .2 seconds. When the experiment varies in some respect (e.g., subject can click with either right or left index finger), the gap between RP-onset and W, though not necessarily the same as in the original version, remains consistent across trials.

The claim that we cannot establish causality because the relative times of events are not measured with quantum accuracy is absurd. No empirical science operates with quantum-level precision, yet we successfully establish causal relationships all the time based on consistent patterns in the data.

Many different Libet-style experiments have been conducted, and they've shown that the length of the RP, as well as the relative positions of RP-onset and W, depend in a consistent manner on the exact task that the subject is being asked to perform. This consistency demonstrates genuine causal relationships rather than mere correlation.

Some philosophers claim Libet confuses urges with intentions, arguing that prior to W, RP is a mere urge and not anything that will by itself lead to action, with W needed to convert this intention-precursor into an actual intention. However, this view contradicts what the graphical data shows about W's causal role.

If W is indeed a decision, then it should have a decisive role in causing the finger-movement. But examining the graphs, W does not have such a decisive role. The finger-movement happens at the vertex of the curve, and it happens because that curve reached its vertex, not because of W's occurrence.

Judging by the graphs, W is the opposite of decisive; it is in the last place that a decision to act would be. If W happened at the very beginning of the slope, it could be a decision (it would clearly be what caused the finger-movement). If it happened at the peak of the slope, it could be a decision (it might convert an erstwhile urge into a veritable intention). But W happens far too late to launch the process and too early to transform it.

According to some philosophers, Libet-actions involve 'disinterested agency' where the agent has no reason to flex their wrist at one particular time rather than another. They call these manifestations of 'liberty of indifference,' suggesting they represent a degenerate or non-paradigmatic form of free will.

Some philosophers suspect that the central or core cases of free will—the kind most intimately related to moral agency—involve deliberation and rational reflection, not the 'liberty of indifference' exemplified in Libet's experiment. However, this position lacks empirical support and appears motivated by a desire to protect traditional conceptions of agency.

The claim that we cannot deduce anything from Libet's results about human action in general because the actions fail to engage rationality or agency is not supported by experimental data. Moreover, the more deliberation and rational reflection are involved in an action, the less likely the operative intention is to be fully conscious.

The actions studied in Libet's experiment are probably not as one-dimensional as some critics make them out to be. If you ask someone to push a button at random intervals, they have to use more thought to follow the instructions than if you asked them to push at regular intervals. In the latter case, one can go on autopilot; in the former, one cannot.

The position that it is a 'phenomenological datum' that we have free will—that we 'just know' we have it, with such knowledge etched into the very structure of the human mind—is straightforwardly question-begging. It assumes the truth of what needs to be demonstrated.

The claim that 'the reality of free will is experienced and not covert to our perceptual perusal' confuses subjective experience with objective reality. The fact that we experience ourselves as having free will does not establish that we actually have it, any more than the fact that subjects in Libet's experiment experienced W as their decision establishes that W was in fact their decision.

Some appeal to the cogito ('I think therefore I am') as providing parallel justification for belief in free will. However, this comparison is misconceived. The cogito is trivial and analytic—its negation is incoherent (I couldn't think unless I existed). But there is nothing trivial about asserting I have free will.

Free will, if it exists, is a form of causation. It is always an open empirical question what causes what. The existence of free will cannot be established by introspection or phenomenological analysis alone but requires empirical investigation of the actual causal structure of decision-making.

Similar studies involving different measuring instruments and different tasks have generated results consistent with Libet's results. This cross-validation using different methodologies strengthens the case for the validity and generalizability of the findings.

When we say Libet's results 'directly establish' certain facts about intentions and consciousness, we mean they establish these facts with the same evidential force that characterizes well-confirmed findings in any empirical science. The standards are no different from those used to establish causal claims in medicine, physics, or biology.

The conscious event that the subject experiences as being identical with his decision is not even involved in that decision as a subordinate part—it is on the sidelines. This is more radical than merely saying consciousness has a limited role; it suggests consciousness has a fundamentally different role than we intuitively assume.

The center of consciousness that each subject identifies as the nucleus of his decision is merely an awareness of that decision, and that decision was made by some other party. This 'other party' is not external to the person but represents unconscious neural processes within that same person.

Compatibilism traditionally says you are free even though you are determined—it doesn't deny that you act. But Libet's experiment shows something more troubling: not that you are determined, but that you are on the sidelines. By the time 'you' (in the sense of your conscious center of experience) make an appearance, the decision has already been made by unconscious processes.

The difference between compatibilism and Libet's findings: It is one thing if your actions resulted from conscious, albeit predetermined, decisions on your part (the compatibilist picture). It is a very different thing if what you thought were the operative conscious decisions are in fact non-operative (what Libet shows).

Libet's experiment is not just rehashing the old idea that choices have causes. It is proof that what we thought were choices aren't actually choices. It is proof that the center of consciousness that a person regards as the nucleus of his very self, and of his agency in particular, isn't actually that nucleus.

Freud showed that some mental activity, including some decisions, are made unconsciously, sometimes with resulting internal conflict. But Freud's position was that consciousness is like a monarch whose power, though considerable, is limited—a weak central authority, not a puppet.

Freud didn't deny that what we take to be our conscious decisions are in fact conscious decisions, nor did he deny that these conscious decisions represented the very nucleus of our agency. In this respect, Freud's view is more compatible with common sense than Libet's findings are.

Libet's work shows that in the very contexts where the conscious ruler least appears to be a puppet (where the subject feels most certain he is calling the shots), that is precisely what he is. He is a mere spectator who isn't even told what the shots are until after they have been fired.

Libet's finding is not compatible with any well-developed philosophical position concerning human agency. All such positions share a foundational assumption: that the events we regard as our conscious choices are indeed our conscious choices. They disagree only about whether those choices are 'free.' Libet's experiment shows this shared assumption to be false.

We need to develop a conception of the mind, specifically of human agency, that accommodates Libet's findings. This requires abandoning or radically revising traditional frameworks that assume conscious experience plays a primary causal role in decision-making.

In the proposed model, 'W' refers to an arbitrary one of the conscious events with which a given person intuitively identifies the intentions governing his so-called 'conscious' actions. Understanding the actual function of W requires distinguishing what we intuitively believe about it from what it actually does.

Even if W is epiphenomenal with respect to the corresponding intention, it is not epiphenomenal tout court (completely without effects). There is evidence that W can 'veto' a pre-existing intention, and W's significance likely extends far beyond that vetoing function.

Consciousness is real-time awareness that takes two forms: real-time awarenesses of external events (sense-perceptions) and real-time awarenesses of internal processes (introspections, broadly construed). Introspections include pains, pleasures, occurrent thoughts about pains and pleasures, mental images, gnawing doubts, inchoate aches, and so on.

One purpose of consciousness is to integrate information about the external world with information about the internal world. Consciousness pools these two datasets, and decisions as to how to maximize the subject's welfare are made on that basis—though not by consciousness itself, as we might intuitively assume.

The presumption is that consciousness makes decisions to maximize welfare, but Libet's results show this is not the case. What consciousness does do is either approve or disapprove of decisions already made. It actively approves of decisions, though these conscious acts of decision-approval are experienced as conscious acts of decision-making.

Why are acts of decision-approval experienced as decision-making rather than as what they actually are? One reason: after a fashion, these acts are decisions—decisions to green-light an existing intention. Another reason: if they were experienced as exactly what they are (approving an intention made by another party), that might overburden consciousness.

One makes innumerably many choices within the space of a single minute. If one's conscious awarenesses of these choices were overly fine-grained, the result would be to bog down consciousness in matters with which it needn't concern itself. The 'illusion of free choice' is a small price to pay for this gain in efficiency.

In approving of a given intention, W implicitly green-lights future similar intentions. It tells the relevant part of one's mind to carry on apace. By parity of reasoning, if W vetoes a given action, it tells that part to redirect its efforts. So W does have a directive role with respect to future intentions.

W serves to approve or disapprove of the intention with which the subject mistakenly believes it to be identical. While not the cause of the particular intention the subject attributes to it, W does influence future intention-formation through its approval/disapproval function.

Looking at Figure 1 from Libet's experiment: suppose you didn't know what this graph represented—all you know is that it describes a growth-process of some kind, and you don't know what 'W' stands for beyond its position on the slope. Under these circumstances, the idea that W is a crucial event in the process in question would seem absurd.

W is the conscious event that the subject believes to be his decision to move his finger. W clearly isn't the cause of the finger-movement. These are the facts, established through repeated experimentation with consistent results across different methodologies and research teams.

One can always play skeptic about empirical findings: 'Libet's experimental data is fraudulent'; 'The actions studied aren't real actions'; 'The actions studied aren't representative'; 'The relation between RP and finger-movement is epiphenomenal, not causal.' These are cards that can be played, but in this context that is all they are—rhetorical moves unsupported by evidence.

Judging by various replication-studies and follow-up studies, there is no reason to believe that Libet's data is in any way spurious and there is every reason to believe that the results generalize to a wide range of decision-making contexts.

Consider the standards of proof and evidence that philosophers are using in connection with data generated by Libet's experiment. By those standards, there is no reason to believe that smoking causes cancer. But it does cause cancer, and we know that because that is what the data shows when properly analyzed and interpreted.

If it turns out that data generated by Libet's experiment and by various replication and follow-up studies is spurious, so be it. In the meantime, we should probably accept that data and try to model it. By refusing to model it—by insisting that it must be spurious—philosophers are blinding themselves to valuable information about the nature of agency.

We have put forth a model, albeit an extremely schematic one, as to the agentive function of conscious mental events like W. If nothing else, our model is consistent with data generated by Libet's experiment. We stand to learn about the mind by investigating the merits of such models rather than by dismissing the data.

We do not stand to learn about the mind by insisting that Libet 'must' be wrong. Such an approach represents intellectual defensiveness rather than genuine scientific inquiry into the nature of consciousness and agency.

Libet's experiment is regarded as an extremely valuable but missed opportunity for the discipline of philosophy. The present analysis is intended to be an attempt, however tentative, to make good on that opportunity by taking the findings seriously and attempting to model them constructively.

One's ability to control the external world, and therefore one's freedom, is abridged to the extent that the external world is indeterministic. If there is a 72% chance a call goes through versus an 84% chance, one has less control with the lower probability. This suggests determinism is necessary for control and therefore for freedom.

One lacks control over oneself, and therefore lacks freedom, to the extent that the internal world is indeterministic. If there is only a 72% chance that one's fingers move when one wants them to move versus an 84% chance, one has less control over oneself and therefore over the world. Determinism appears necessary for power over oneself and therefore for freedom.

If thought-processes are not predetermined, they come out of nowhere—they aren't rooted in one's beliefs, values, or intentions; they are mere visitations. If thoughts totally lacked a causal basis in one's pre-existing psychological structures and the physiological structures mediating them, it is unclear why those thoughts would be his thoughts; they would be free-floating thoughts.

Thoughts that lacked a causal basis in one's pre-existing condition would seem to be intrusions—similar to an obsessive-compulsive's 'intrusive thoughts.' Though uncaused, they would not represent that person exercising his agency; indeed, they would be undergone by him and therefore would neither give him freedom nor represent deployments of any freedom he might have.

Indeterminism threatens freedom. There doesn't seem to be any respect in which any form of indeterminism makes us free. Determinism may also threaten freedom in some sense, but determinism seems to be a prerequisite for freedom, at least insofar as it is possible to have freedom.

There seems to be at least a kind of freedom compatible with determinism: I am acting freely, at least after a fashion, when my actions align with my values and represent a fulfillment of my biological program. If in making a decision I am exercising my rationality to the greatest extent possible and choosing a path that will enhance me rather than diminish me, then arguably I am acting freely in the only sense that is possible or even conceivable.
