Libet's results are quite clear regarding a specific class of actions: When it comes to actions involved in real-time engagements with the environment, intention-mediating RP's predate the conscious events that people are inclined to believe are their intentions. There is nothing unclear about this fact per se.

If it isn't clear how Libet's results bear on questions about free will, that is because the concept of free will itself is unclear, not because Libet's results are unclear. We don't have a precise understanding of what it means to say someone has 'free will,' what a 'self' is, or whether there is a self wherever there is sentience.

Most philosophers who have written on the significance of Libet's experiment have attempted to trivialize it rather than take it seriously as a challenge to traditional frameworks. Some have taken the position that the actual data generated by the experiment is spurious; others claim the brain-activity preceding W is not causative of W.

Philosophers seldom if ever ask: 'What does the Libet experiment show?' Instead, they ask: 'What does the experiment show about free will?' The first question is open-ended and demands that we evaluate results on their own terms. The second question demands that we evaluate the perspicuous experimental data in terms of the vagaries of the concept of free will.

Little is gained by discussing Libet's results in terms of their bearing on 'whether we have free will,' for the very question concedes too much validity to assumptions about the nature of agency, and indeed the composition of the mind, that the results call into question. Little is gained by evaluating results in terms of their bearing on 'incompatibilism' or 'libertarianism.'

Nothing is gained, and much is lost, by trying to press Libet's results into the service of a pre-existing philosophical agenda. Most importantly, nothing is gained by responding defensively to the results—by trying to diminish or circumscribe their significance.

Libet's results clearly are significant, and they almost certainly do generalize, granting that it is an open question exactly how they generalize. The task is to understand what they reveal about the mind rather than to defend pre-existing philosophical positions against them.

The subject in Libet's experiment is free to press the button whenever he wants—it is entirely up to him when to press it. He does not have to press the button when some external condition is met (when he hears a certain sound, for example). This makes the action paradigmatically 'free' in the ordinary sense of that term.

Heat-sensitive pads were attached to the subject's cranium and connected via wires to a machine that measured electrical activity in the subject's brain activity on the basis of the resulting temperature-readings. This provided a non-invasive way to track neural activity associated with the decision-making process.

The subject had a clock in front of him with a rapidly moving millisecond hand to help him pinpoint the time at which he was first consciously aware of his intention to press the button. This allowed for precise temporal correlation between subjective conscious experience and objective neural activity.

Just as we would expect, conscious awareness (W) slightly precedes the resulting finger-movement. But as the graph shows, the subject is conscious of his intention only after it has long been in the making. The subject always feels as though he 'just came up with' the decision and that he 'freely' chose to move his finger.

The subject always feels that his decision (the conscious event that he took to be his decision) was not the result of any previous mentation on his part. It was not, so he felt, the result of deliberation or of any sort of psychological activity that might be dispositive of it. The subject described his decision as utterly 'free.'

This experiment was repeated by Libet himself and by others with hundreds of different subjects, always with the same results. The shape and length of the slope was always the same, as was the length of the gap between RP-initiation and W, and the gap between W and the corresponding finger-movement.

By the time W happens, RP is almost complete. So even if W is a part of the intention that led to the action, it is a subordinate part with at most a facilitating function. Intentions and decisions are supposed to have a decisive role in the genesis of corresponding actions, and W clearly does not have such a role.

If we simply insisted that W was the relevant intention, we would be taking the incoherent view that intentions did not have a decisive role in the genesis of the corresponding actions. This would contradict our basic understanding of what intentions are.

W is not a mere epiphenomenon in the absolute sense. Consciousness of one's intentions necessarily has effects: If I am aware of a given intention of mine, my subsequent thought and behavior will necessarily be different from how they would otherwise have been.

W, though not the intention responsible for the finger-movement in question, clearly does have a hand in generating other intentions down the road. This is trivially true of any intentions that relate to learning about W itself, and it almost certainly holds of intentions that do not fall into this category.

W presupposes the existence of the operative intention and is therefore either an awareness of it or a decidedly subordinate part of it. The evidence suggests W is not a part of that intention at all but rather an awareness of it.

W happens very late in the game: whatever is responsible for the finger-movement is well under way by the time W makes an appearance. The position that the pre-W part of the RP is intention-buildup rather than the intention proper, with W being the intention proper, would be absurd in any other context.

Suppose the graph concerned the growth in value of Warren Buffet's stock portfolio and W were some related event like Buffet buying shares of Microsoft. If we said W was what put Buffet in the black, our position would have no plausibility at all. We would have no reason to regard W as contributing to the portfolio growth other than at most helping to continue it.

In different representations of Libet's data, W either has no effect or a slight negative effect on the trajectory of the slope. In one figure it has no effect—it is not an inflection-point of any kind. In another it is a slight negative inflection point where the graph's slope decreases slightly after W.

If W were indeed the decision responsible for the finger-movement, the graph would inflect upwards after W rather than failing to inflect or inflecting negatively. Judging by one figure, W's role, if anything, is to curb the causally effective process. Judging by another, W's role is indeterminate but clearly not decisive.

W cannot possibly be an intention, let alone a decision, since such things are of their nature decisive causes. The graphical representation of the data makes this clear through the position and effects of W relative to the overall process culminating in action.

One answer to the question of W's causal role is that W is the operative intention. But we've seen this is false based on careful analysis of the temporal relationships and graphical representations. Another answer is that W does nothing—it is an 'epiphenomenon.' But this too is false, as W is operative in contexts beyond the particular finger-movement being studied.
